Our courses provide a rich learning experience that will allow you to develop critical business skills in areas such as business... Read more...
title: Diploma in Warehouse Management
headline: This free online diploma course provides the skills required to be a successful warehouse manager.
description: This course teaches you everything you need to know to manage a warehouse. We explore topics like supply chain management, health and safety concerns and managing staff to train you to run an efficient warehouse. We also examine effective technological solutions employed in modern warehouses. This diploma certification course can help to move upwards at work and puts you on a management track.

courseDescription:
This course equips you with the skills and knowledge necessary to become a successful warehouse manager. We cover the basics of warehouse management and explain its role in modern supply chains. This understanding can buttress your skillset and boost your career.

We examine warehouse technology, practices and management systems. The course shows you how to manage people and their health and safety requirements. We break down the process of controlling inventory and managing costs into easy steps. The course includes assessments and exercises to help you track your progress.

Warehouses play an essential role in modern supply chain management. With growing global trade and soaring e-commerce sales, warehouse managers are responsible for meeting consumer demands. This course trains you to manage your own warehouse with confidence so sign up to gain vital skills that can launch your career to its next level.

Start Course Now
certificateDetail:
All Alison courses are free to enrol study and complete. To successfully complete this diploma course and become an Alison Graduate, you need to achieve 80% or higher in each course assessment. Once you have completed this diploma course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison diploma is:
  • Ideal for sharing with potential employers
  • Include it in your CV, professional social media profiles and job applications.
  • An indication of your commitment to continuously learn, upskill & achieve high results.
  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.
Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:
  • Digital diploma: a downloadable diploma in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • diploma: a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked diploma, posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed diploma: a physical version of your officially branded and security marked diploma in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.
Start Course Now

All diploma are available to purchase through the Alison Shop. For more information on purchasing Alison diploma, please visit our FAQs. If you decide not to purchase your Alison diploma, you can still demonstrate your achievement by sharing your Learner Record or Learner Achievement Verification, both of which are accessible from your Dashboard. For more details on our diploma pricing, please visit our Pricing Page

modules.name: Module
modules.details: The Basic Principles of Warehouse Management
modules.description: This module focuses on the basics of warehouse management. We will examine the functions of modern warehouses, important factors of warehouse location and the guiding principles of warehouse design.
topics: The Basic Principles of Warehouse Management - Learning Outcomes
Functions of Warehouses in Modern Supply Chains
Number of Warehouses Required and Design Principles
The Basic Principles of Warehouse Management - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.details: Technology and Trends in Warehouse Management
modules.description: This module gives you the tools you need to think about and make decisions regarding warehouse technology. We begin by introducing technological equipment commonly used in warehouses. This course also briefly examines outsourcing. We will investigate robotics and finally, we provide you with tips on how to adapt to new technologies.
topics: Technology and Trends in Warehouse Management - Learning Outcomes
Technology and Trends in Warehouse Management - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.description: This module guides you through each of the most important warehouse processes, giving you the information you need to ensure things are well organised and run as smoothly as possible. We begin by focusing on the work involved in receiving, organising, and storing products. In addition, we discuss the details involved in dispatching goods. Finally, we cover the challenges posed by increasingly lenient corporate return policies.
topics: Warehouse Organisation and Storage of Goods

modules.name: Module
modules.description: This module discusses the picking process as it relates to warehouse management. We talk about the numerous picking methods and systems available to modern warehouse managers. We also provide you with ways to improve your picking productivity. Finally, we cover the factors you should keep in mind when deciding on the best way to manage your warehouse picking processes.
topics: Picking and Warehouse Management - Learning Outcomes
Picking and Warehouse Management - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.description: This module guides you through everything you need to know to become a better inventory manager. We begin by talking about your warehouse layout, helping you optimise product position to help your staff manage inventory levels with ease. We also talk about how to manage and accurately track your inventory, including a discussion about the importance of consistent auditing. Finally, we talk about reducing your inventory costs, giving you a few technological tips and tricks to keep in mind.

modules.name: Module
modules.description: This module discusses the most important inventory management tasks: controlling, verifying, and reporting stock. We begin the module by providing you with the best practices for controlling stock movement within a warehouse, along with methods for stock verification. We then discuss the most important reports for warehouse managers to complete. The module closes by offering solutions to common challenges faced by those trying to determine which warehouse management software is best.
topics: Controlling, Verifying, and Reporting Stock - Learning Outcomes
Controlling, Verifying, and Reporting Stock - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.details: Inventory and Supply Chain in a Warehouse
modules.description: This module talks about the supply chain in detail, giving you information on its main function, along with some common processes. We also talk about ways to optimise your supply chain, improving productivity while cutting back costs. In addition, information about the various inventory decisions you need to make as a warehouse manager is provided. Finally, we talk about troubleshooting and problem-solving techniques, to help your warehouse continue to be a successful part of the supply chain.
topics: Inventory and Supply Chain in a Warehouse - Learning Outcomes
The Main Function of Supply Chains
Inventory and Supply Chain in a Warehouse - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.description: This module outlines the most important staffing issues to keep in mind. Attracting and hiring the best available labour force is the first important step. We also talk about disciplinary techniques, and provide you with conflict resolution tips and tricks. Keeping your workforce engaged and motivated is another important aspect of warehouse management discussed in this module. Finally, we talk about the importance of complying with local legislation.
topics: Managing People in a Warehouse - Learning Outcomes
Conflict Resolution, Motivating Staff and Legislation
Managing People in a Warehouse - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.description: This module covers the importance of warehouse safety. We start by giving you information about developing a comprehensive health and safety plan, followed by a discussion of proper materials handling procedures. Risk assessment is another key part of maintaining a safe warehouse, as is learning how to minimise its effect. Finally, we give you a few things to keep in mind should an emergency or accident occur.
topics: Safety in a Warehouse - Learning Outcomes
Developing and Enforcing a Health and Safety Plan
Materials Handling Procedure and Risk Assessment
Mitigating or Minimising Risk and Damage Control
Safety in a Warehouse - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.description: This module is the last one in the Warehouse Management course, tying everything you have learned so far together. In this module, we break down the categories of warehouse expenses, helping you identify where your costs go. We then discuss how to manage your labour expenses, as this tends to be where the majority of your budget goes. Slotting is another important thing to consider when thinking about costs, and we talk about its importance as well. Finally, we cover the best uses of technology.

slides:
• Learning Outcomes

  • After successfully completing this course, you will be able to:
    • Describe the main functions of a warehouse in modern supply chains.
    • Identify the challenges warehouse managers face.
    • Explain how to determine the location of the warehouse. 
    • List the factors to consider when thinking about the number of warehouses required.
    • Discuss the guiding principles behind warehouse design.

  • Functions of Warehouses in Modern Supply Chains 

  • Warehouses have always been critical to the supply chain. Historically, a warehouse housed excess product, and recent shipments businesses could not stock in brick-and-mortar stores. Controlling inventory was the only major responsibility of warehouse managers.

    Of course, warehouses still play this crucial role for companies across the globe. However, recent changes in how businesses operate mean that warehouses must serve several other functions as well. One big reason for this shift is the changing way consumers purchase their products. Many businesses offer online ordering and rely on well-run warehouses to deliver goods to their customers.

    In general, consumers demand fast delivery time, with no patience for lengthy delays. As a result, a fully stocked warehouse with accurate inventory counts is crucial to a company’s reputation. Understanding the many roles it has to play is the foundation of effective management.

  • Functions of Warehouses in Modern Supply Chains

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Challenges

  • Managing a warehouse often involves a bit of stress. There are many things that could go wrong, affecting your company’s bottom line. In general, these potential challenges fall into five categories. Anticipating these problems before they arise helps lessen the impact on your business.
    • New Tab

    • Unclear Inventory Location

    • Inefficient Utilisation of Space  and Poor Warehouse Layouts 

    • Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipisicing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua..
      Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipisicing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua..
    • Inventory uncertainty always leads to numerous errors and complications. Everyone in the warehouse needs to know where to find any given item at any given time. Unfamiliarity slows down production, delays shipment, and may increase costs. For example, if a picker cannot locate a particular item, the loading process slows down, affecting shipping.

      An automated process that can catalogue products as they arrive often addresses this problem. Carefully designing and planning your warehouse also prevents the risk of lost or misplaced inventory.
      Inventory uncertainty always leads to numerous errors and complications. Everyone in the warehouse needs to know where to find any given item at any given time. Unfamiliarity slows down production, delays shipment, and may increase costs. For example, if a picker cannot locate a particular item, the loading process slows down, affecting shipping.

      An automated process that can catalogue products as they arrive often addresses this problem. Carefully designing and planning your warehouse also prevents the risk of lost or misplaced inventory.

    • It is important to make use of all the space available to you when planning your warehouse. Wasted space costs your company money. Taking advantage of your storage area’s height often doubles the amount of space available to you. Consider purchasing racks and pallets to facilitate this type of storage system.

      Poor warehouse layouts present another kind of challenge to management. Inefficient layouts negatively impact productivity and often result in unnecessary work by your staff. When thinking about your warehouse layout, prioritise easy access to common items.

  • Factors Affecting Number and Size of Warehouses

    • New Tab
    • Number of Warehouses
    • Warehouse Size

      Customer ID
      Customer Name
    • The appropriate number of warehouses required depends on many factors. These factors - including the type of product, its size, and its rate of sale - all impact the amount of space a company requires. Warehouse managers also consider the location of any existing warehouses and the cost of transportation when thinking about the number required.

      Some companies opt to open multiple warehouses in different places, resulting in faster shipping times to target markets. Others have one main warehouse and operate temporary ones as sales fluctuate. The best way to make this decision is to figure out the most cost-effective approach for your company.
      The appropriate number of warehouses required depends on many factors. These factors - including the type of product, its size, and its rate of sale - all impact the amount of space a company requires. Warehouse managers also consider the location of any existing warehouses and the cost of transportation when thinking about the number required.

      Some companies opt to open multiple warehouses in different places, resulting in faster shipping times to target markets. Others have one main warehouse and operate temporary ones as sales fluctuate. The best way to make this decision is to figure out the most cost-effective approach for your company.

      Customer ID
      Customer Name
    • When thinking about the size of your warehouse, consider the size, storage conditions, and shipping time of your products. If you primarily store small items that sell and ship fast, you may want several smaller warehouses spread across your distribution area. Companies that offer larger products or those requiring special storage solutions need to look for larger warehouses with extra space.

      Figuring out the size and number of warehouses required seems like a complicated task. Thankfully, there are industry-specific software tools available that guide warehouse managers through this decision process.
      When thinking about the size of your warehouse, consider the size, storage conditions, and shipping time of your products. Warehouse managers also consider the location of any existing warehouses and the cost of transportation when thinking about the number required.

      Some companies opt to open multiple warehouses in different places, resulting in faster shipping times to target markets. Others have one main warehouse and operate temporary ones as sales fluctuate. The best way to make this decision is to figure out the most cost-effective approach for your company.

    • Warehouse Size
      When thinking about the size of your warehouse, consider the size, storage conditions, and shipping time of your products. If you primarily store small items that sell and ship fast, you may want several smaller warehouses spread across your distribution area. Companies that offer larger products or those requiring special storage solutions need to look for larger warehouses with extra space.

      Figuring out the size and number of warehouses required seems like a complicated task. Thankfully, there are industry-specific software tools available that guide warehouse managers through this decision process.
